content.description: Sit start to Samson. Start down & right of the Samson start jug, on a small right-facing rail. Crux is the move to the Samson start jug.
content.location: Middle of the gently overhung face closest the stream.

content.description: Start at a right-facing jug fairly high up. Shorter climbers may have to jump to it. Up left to a smallish rail, then a big move to a quartz jug close to the top. Keep it together on the tall but juggy topout.
content.location: Middle of the gently overhung face closest the stream.

content.description: Climb the side of the diagonal slab closest to the road. The crack up the middle offers great holds. Good warm up.

Climb the arete left of the gaping offwidth. Not a lot of lichen anymore thanks to whoever scrubbed it.

 The top of this climb provides a look at the techniques that were used to break boulders apart into stone. Thankfully, in this case the project was aborted midway leaving us this beautiful boulder to climb.
Climb the cracks and arete to the right of the offwidth.

Climb the center of the slabby side of the main boulder on good holds to a cruxy move at the top.

 This problem tops out near the large metal implement embedded in the boulder's top. As of 2018 fixed webbing is in place to ease the descent.

Steep hand crack, anywhere from #.75 to #4 at the top.  I voted v2-3 (with adult male hands and some crack experience) as I think it would correlate as a solid 5.11 crux.  The boulder is tall and the top out is not trivial.
content.protection: NOTE* there is no easy down-climb, I went down the squeeze chimney which was not so bad
content.location: Obvious overhanging crack on side of boulder facing creek. Not too far from some houses so be respectful of that
Slab on the left boulder, close to the arete.

content.description:
This boulder is so named because it is actually two boulder that come out of the ground at an angle to make them look like one massive semi-buried part-way open book. 

  Both boulders have problems although the far said has most of the lines (6 total I think) that range in grade from V0- squeeze chimney to V6 overhanging finger to hand crack.
